Title: Object: The new consular waltz
Description: Seven women toss Napoleon in a blanket. He flies into the air, wearing his hat; he says: "Oh! that I were safe in Egypt!" His sabre lies broken on the ground. The women say: [1] "Up with him to the Shies [sic]"; "Give him plenty of it"; "He delights in high Stations!" [2] "Pauvre diable!!! is that the Hero who is to conquer England!!!" [3] "We'll toss your Soul out of you!" [4] "Up with him again!" [5] "You sent my Sweetheart to St Domingo!" [see BMSat 9842]. [6] "Well Bunny have you built any more Castles since you've been up in the Air! Or will you [sic] some more Conscripts to help you." [7] "Well, are you come to your Senses yet;? Can you behave peaceably." In the background (left) a Dutchman and a Spanish don sit together at a table. Both watch the scene, the Dutchman, who is smoking, with delight. 29 May 1803 Hand-coloured etching
Curator's comments: (Description and comment from M.Dorothy George, 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires in the British Museum', VIII, 1947) This theme was elaborated by Rowlandson, 'Friends & Foes - up he goes . . .', 12 Dec. 1813. An early allusion to Napoleon's conscripts, a popular theme from 1813. See also BMSats 10075, 10117, 10597. Broadley, i. 173-4.
Bibliographic references: BM Satires / Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum (10001)
Associated names: Associated with: Napoléon I, Emperor of the French (Napoleon)
